[[Enrique Plancarte Solís]] | party = | boards = | spouse = | partner = | children = | parents = | relatives = | signature = | website = | footnotes = $2.2 million dollar reward was offered. }} {{Spanish name|Moreno|González}} '''Nazario Moreno González''' (8 March 1970 – 9 March 2014), commonly referred to by his alias '''El Chayo''' ("Nazario" or "The Rosary") and/or '''El Más Loco''' ("The Craziest One"), was a [[Mexican people|Mexican]] [[drug lord]] who headed [[La Familia Michoacana]] before heading the [[Knights Templar Cartel]], a drug cartel headquartered in the state of [[Michoacán]]. He was one of Mexico's [[List of Mexico's 37 most-wanted drug lords|most-wanted drug lords]]. Very few details are known of Moreno González's early life, but the authorities believe that religion played a major role in his upbringing. Although born in Michoacán, Moreno González moved to the United States as a teenager, but fled back into Mexico about a decade later to avoid prosecution on drug trafficking charges. In 2004, the drug boss [[Carlos Rosales Mendoza]] was captured, and Moreno González, alongside [[José de Jesús Méndez Vargas]], took control of [[La Familia Michoacana]]. Unlike other traditional drug trafficking organizations in Mexico, his organization also operated like a religious cult, where its own members were given "bibles" with sayings and conduct guidelines. Moreno González reportedly carried out several philanthropic deeds to help the marginalized in Michoacán. Such deeds helped him craft an image of protector, saint, and Christ-like messianic figure among the poor, and gave La Familia Michoacana a level of influence among some natives. The Mexican government reported that Moreno González was killed during a two-day gunfight with the [[Federal Police (Mexico)|Mexican federal police]] in his home state in December 2010. After the shootout, however, no body was recovered. Rumors thus persisted that Moreno González was still alive and leading the Knights Templar Cartel, the split-off group of La Familia Michoacana. Four years later, on 9 March 2014, his survival was confirmed. Mexican authorities located him again, this time in the town of [[Tumbiscatío|Tumbiscatío, Michoacán]], and attempted to apprehend him. A gunfight ensued resulting in Moreno González's death. Subsequent forensic examination confirmed his identity. ==Criminal career== ===Early life=== Moreno González was born in the ''[[ranchería]]'' of Guanajuatillo in [[Apatzingán|Apatzingán, Michoacán]], Mexico at around 5:00 a.m. on 8 March 1970.{{cite news|title=Veneran a fundador de la Familia Michoacana|url=http://eleconomista.com.mx/sociedad/2012/07/10/veneran-fundador-familia-michoacana|accessdate=14 November 2012|newspaper=[[El Economista (Mexico)|El Economista]]|date=10 July 2012|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6CArgKCuq?url=http://eleconomista.com.mx/sociedad/2012/07/10/veneran-fundador-familia-michoacana|archivedate=14 November 2012|deadurl=no|language=Spanish}}{{cite news|last=Becerra Acosta|first=Juan Pablo|title="El más loco" jugó a la muerte y la resurrección... desde niño|url=http://www.milenio.com/policia/loco-jugo-muerte-resurreccion-nino_0_263373685.html|archivedate=17 March 2014|newspaper=[[Milenio]]|date=16 March 2014|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6O8KwoWbr?url=http://www.milenio.com/policia/loco-jugo-muerte-resurreccion-nino_0_263373685.html|language=Spanish|deadurl=no|accessdate=10 June 2017|df=dmy-all}} There are few details of Moreno González's upbringing, but religion may have played an important role in his early life.{{sfn|Longmire|2011|p=26}} His parents had 13 children (including Moreno González). His father Manuel Moreno was reportedly an alcoholic and had several mistresses, and one day he left his family when Moreno González was still very young, forcing his mother to singlehandedly raise the whole family. With their father gone, Moreno González and his siblings lived under the strict discipline of their mother. According to his autobiography, Moreno González had a love-hate relationship with his mother; as a child, he was beaten by his mother for being troublesome and getting into fights. In one occasion, he recalled that his mother once forced him to make his way back to his house by walking on his knees while keeping his arms stretched like a cross throughout the whole day for stealing an animal. Such treatments helped him develop resentment as to partially explain his violent behavior as an adult, he argued. He admitted, however, that he often got into fist fights with other kids from Guanajuatillo and the surrounding ''rancherías''. Moreno González recalled that he would not always win and that he once got into 10 fights in a single day. His violent reputation as a child helped him earn the nickname El Más Loco ("The Craziest One")—which he held onto for the rest of his life—among his siblings and other kids from the area where he grew up. He never attended school and was illiterate for some years of his early life. He learned to read and write reportedly out of curiosity after reading and hearing comic books and stories of ''[[Kalimán]]'' and ''Porfirio Cadena, El Ojo del Vidrio'' on the local radio station.{{cite news|title=El Chayo escribió un libro autobiográfico|url=http://www.zocalo.com.mx/seccion/articulo/el-chayo-escribio-un-libro-autobiografico-1394979133|accessdate=17 March 2014|newspaper=Zócalo Saltillo|date=16 March 2014|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6O8Ltv4Z5?url=http://www.zocalo.com.mx/seccion/articulo/el-chayo-escribio-un-libro-autobiografico-1394979133|archivedate=17 March 2014|language=Spanish}} In his autobiography, Moreno González said that as a child he believed he had the superhuman ability of speaking telepathically with animals like ''Kalimán'' did in the comics. He said he wanted to be a hero like the comic characters. As a child, he was accustomed to seeing gunmen near his home, and played ''las guerritas'' ("war games") for fun. While playing the game, he often pretended to be dead, only to say later on that he had been wounded in the game but that he had managed to survive. At the age of twelve, he moved to Apatzingán and made a living by selling [[match]]es, peeling onions, working at a melon field, and throwing out the trash from several booths at a marketplace.{{cite news|last=Herrera Cornejo|first=Arturo|title=El Chayo|url=http://www.lajornadamichoacan.com.mx/2014/03/10/el-chayo/|accessdate=17 March 2014|newspaper=[[La Jornada]]|date=10 March 2014|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6O8LmzKKg?url=http://www.lajornadamichoacan.com.mx/2014/03/10/el-chayo/|archivedate=17 March 2014|language=Spanish}} As a teenager in the late 1980s, Moreno González [[Illegal immigration to the United States|migrated illegally to the United States]], settling in California, where he eventually began selling marijuana.{{cite news|last=Castellanos|first=Francisco J.|title=El Chayo, santo patrono de la tierra caliente|url=http://www.proceso.com.mx/?p=316163|accessdate=14 November 2012|newspaper=[[Proceso (magazine)|Proceso]]|date=4 August 2012|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6CBH77PZR?url=http://www.proceso.com.mx/?p=316163|archivedate=15 November 2012|deadurl=no|language=Spanish|df=dmy-all}}{{cite news|last=Olson|first=Alexandra|title=Brutal Mexican La Familia cartel chief killed|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/americas/brutal-mexican-la-familia-cartel-chief-killed-2157693.html|accessdate=14 November 2012|newspaper=[[The Independent]]|date=11 December 2010|agency=[[The Associated Press]]|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6CBHDJHdi?url=http://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/americas/brutal-mexican-la-familia-cartel-chief-killed-2157693.html|archivedate=15 November 2012|deadurl=no}} After some years, he moved to Texas and in 1994 was arrested for drug trafficking charges in [[McAllen, Texas|McAllen]]. Nearly a decade later in 2003, the U.S. government charged him with [[conspiracy (crime)|conspiracy]] to distribute five tons of narcotics and issued an arrest warrant. Moreno González then fled back to Mexico.{{cite news|last=Shoichet|first=Catherine E.|title=Mexican government: Slain drug lord was 'spiritual leader' of cartel|url=http://www.cnn.com/2010/WORLD/americas/12/11/mexico.drug.lord.killed/index.html|accessdate=14 November 2012|newspaper=[[CNN]]|date=11 December 2010|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6CBHJf1TK?url=http://www.cnn.com/2010/WORLD/americas/12/11/mexico.drug.lord.killed/index.html|archivedate=15 November 2012|deadurl=no}} ===Organized crime=== Although raised [[Catholicism|Catholic]], Moreno González became a [[Jehovah's Witness]] during his time in the United States.{{cite news|title=Cartel bosses behind Mexico's violent drug wars|url=http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/41854533/ns/world_news-americas/#.UKPNQuOe_DE|accessdate=14 November 2012|newspaper=[[MSNBC]]|agency=[[NBC News]]|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6CAmNgzZj?url=http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/41854533/ns/world_news-americas/|archivedate=14 November 2012|deadurl=no}}{{cite news|last=Rivera|first=Alicia|title=Preocupa a católicos la conversión de "El Chayo|url=http://www.milenio.com/cdb/doc/impreso/8880342|accessdate=14 November 2012|newspaper=[[Milenio]]|date=13 December 2010|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6CAmeLiK7?url=http://www.milenio.com/cdb/doc/impreso/8880342|archivedate=14 November 2012|deadurl=no|language=Spanish}} In Apatzingán, Moreno González preached to the poor and always carried a bible with him. With time, he won the loyalty of several locals, and many started to see him as a "[[messiah]]" for preaching religious principles and forming La Familia Michoacana, a drug cartel that posed as a vigilante group.{{sfn|Longmire|2011|p=26}} When [[Carlos Rosales Mendoza]] was arrested in 2004, Moreno González ascended to the apex of [[La Familia Michoacana]], a drug trafficking organization based in western Mexico, along with [[José de Jesús Méndez Vargas]].{{cite web|last=Benson|first=Rodney G.|title=Is Merida Antiquated? Part Two: Updating US Policy to Counter Threats of Insurgency and Narco-Terrorism|url=http://www.justice.gov/dea/pr/speeches-testimony/2012-2009/111003_testimony.pdf|publisher=[[United States Department of Justice]]|accessdate=14 November 2012|page=6|date=4 October 2011|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6CBHTgx2Q?url=http://www.justice.gov/dea/pr/speeches-testimony/2012-2009/111003_testimony.pdf|archivedate=15 November 2012|deadurl=no}} In 2006, La Familia Michoacana broke relations with the [[Gulf Cartel]] and [[Los Zetas]], and Moreno González heralded the organization's independence when several of his gunmen tossed five human heads on a discothèque dance floor in [[Uruapan, Michoacán|Uruapan]]. Near the severed heads lay a message that read, "La Familia doesn't kill for money, doesn't kill women, doesn't kill innocents. Only those who deserve to die will die." In 2009, the Mexican government published a list of its [[List of Mexico's 37 most-wanted drug lords|37 most-wanted drug lords]] and offered a $2.2 million reward for information that led to Moreno González's capture.{{cite news|title=Mexico offers $2 million for top drug lords|url=http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/29839838/#.UKPL8-Oe_DE|accessdate=14 November 2012|newspaper=[[MSNBC]]|date=23 March 2009|agency=[[The Associated Press]]|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6CAlyBVGn?url=http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/29839838/|archivedate=14 November 2012|deadurl=no}} His three partners – [[José de Jesús Méndez Vargas]], [[Servando Gómez Martínez]] and [[Dionisio Loya Plancarte]] – were also on the list.{{cite news|last=Olson|first=Alexandra|title=Mexico offers $2 million for top drug lords|url=http://www.elpasotimes.com/ci_11978412|accessdate=14 November 2012|newspaper=[[El Paso Times]]|date=23 March 2009|agency=[[The Associated Press]]|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6CAqsxyVD?url=http://www.elpasotimes.com/ci_11978412|archivedate=14 November 2012|deadurl=yes|df=dmy-all}} In 2010, he was sanctioned under the [[Foreign Narcotics Kingpin Designation Act]] (sometimes referred to simply as the "Kingpin Act") by the [[United States Department of the Treasury]] for his involvement in drug trafficking. The act prohibited U.S. citizens and companies from doing business with Moreno González, and virtually froze all his assets in the U.S.{{cite web|title=Federal Register Volume 75, Number 41|url=http://www.gpo.gov/fdsys/pkg/FR-2010-03-03/html/2010-4373.htm|publisher=[[United States Department of the Treasury]]|accessdate=28 May 2014|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140528051854/http://www.gpo.gov/fdsys/pkg/FR-2010-03-03/html/2010-4373.htm|archivedate=28 May 2014|date=3 March 2010}} Los Zetas eventually broke off from the Gulf Cartel in 2010, after serving in the armed wing of the organization for more than a decade. But in opposition to Los Zetas, Moreno González's cartel rejoined with the Gulf Cartel and allied with the [[Sinaloa Cartel]] to fight them off.{{cite news|last=De la Luz González|first=María|title=PF: cártel del Golfo y "La Familia" son aliados|url=http://www.eluniversal.com.mx/nacion/176934.html|accessdate=15 November 2012|newspaper=[[El Universal (Mexico City)|El Universal]]|date=13 April 2010|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6CBHawwbs?url=http://www.eluniversal.com.mx/nacion/176934.html|archivedate=15 November 2012|deadurl=no|language=Spanish}} Since then, La Familia Michoacana became one of the fastest-growing cartels involved in [[Mexican Drug War|Mexico's drug war]]. It stood out for its promotion of "family values" and religious agenda, unlike traditional cartels.{{cite news|title=La Familia party leads Mexico police to Nazario Moreno|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-11995554|accessdate=14 November 2012|newspaper=[[BBC News]]|date=14 December 2010|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6CApISYTD?url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-11995554|archivedate=14 November 2012|deadurl=no}}{{cite news|last=Wilkinson|first=Tracy|title=Mexico drug traffickers corrupt politics|url=http://www.latimes.com/news/nationworld/world/la-fg-michoacan-drugs31-2009may31,0,3065365,full.story|accessdate=14 November 2012|newspaper=[[Los Angeles Times]]|date=31 March 2009|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110305025010/http://www.latimes.com/news/nationworld/world/la-fg-michoacan-drugs31-2009may31,0,3065365,full.story|archivedate=5 March 2011 |deadurl=no}} Although deeply involved in the [[methamphetamine]] business, Moreno González's cartel diversified its criminal agenda by controlling numerous "counterfeiting, extortion, kidnapping, armed robbery, prostitution and car dealership" rings in Michoacán and its neighboring states. By mid-2009, La Familia had managed to establish a foothold in about 20 to 30 urban areas across the United States. Moreno González required his men to carry a "spiritual manual" that he wrote himself, "[containing] pseudo-Christian [[aphorisms]] for self-improvement."{{cite news|last=Booth|first=William|title=A Mexican Cartel's Swift and Grisly Climb|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2009/06/12/AR2009061203829.html?sid=ST2009061204134|accessdate=14 November 2012|newspaper=[[The Washington Post]]|date=13 June 2009|agency=[[The Washington Post Company]]|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6CAmBarv4?url=http://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2009/06/12/AR2009061203829.html?sid=ST2009061204134|archivedate=14 November 2012|deadurl=yes|df=dmy-all}}{{cite news|last=Chalk|first=Peter|title=Profiles of Mexico's Seven Major Drug Trafficking Organizations|url=http://www.ctc.usma.edu/posts/profiles-of-mexicos-seven-major-drug-trafficking-organizations|accessdate=14 November 2012|newspaper=[[Combating Terrorism Center]]|date=18 June 2012|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6CAqicKSf?url=http://www.ctc.usma.edu/posts/profiles-of-mexicos-seven-major-drug-trafficking-organizations|archivedate=14 November 2012|deadurl=no}} In his "bible," Moreno González prohibited his men from consuming [[alcoholic beverage]]s or other [[drug]]s, and stated that he would severely punish those who mistreated women. His writings encouraged the corporal punishment of thieves by beating them and making them walk naked with billboards in the city streets.{{sfn|Lyman|2010|p=297}} He prohibited members of his cartel from consuming or selling methamphetamines in Michoacán, arguing that the drug was only to be smuggled into the U.S. for American consumers.{{cite news|last=Fausset|first=Ricard|title=In life, Mexican cartel boss was revered as a saint|url=http://www.chicagotribune.com/topic/la-fg-mexico-mas-loco-20140311,0,6914705,full.story|accessdate=11 March 2014|newspaper=[[Chicago Tribune]]|date=11 March 2014|agency=Original story posted by [[Los Angeles Times]]|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140311081733/http://www.chicagotribune.com/topic/la-fg-mexico-mas-loco-20140311,0,6914705,full.story|archivedate=11 March 2014|deadurl=no}} Moreno González justified drug trafficking by stating that La Familia Michoacana allegedly regulated the drug trade to prevent exploitation of the people.{{cite news|title=Personalities: El Chayo|url=http://www.insightcrime.org/personalities-mexico/nazario-moreno-gonzalez-el-chayo-el-mas-loco|accessdate=15 November 2012|newspaper=[[InSight Crime]]|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121115000000/http://www.insightcrime.org/personalities-mexico/nazario-moreno-gonzalez-el-chayo-el-mas-loco|archivedate=15 November 2012|deadurl=no}} The book, sometimes known as "The Sayings of the Craziest One", also talks about humility, service, wisdom, brotherhood, courage, and God.{{cite news|title=El Chayo, el pastor que creó un cartel de narcotráfico|url=http://www.br.terra.com/terramagazine/interna/0,,EI10781-OI4838527,00.html|accessdate=15 November 2012|newspaper=[[Terra Networks]]|date=10 December 2010|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121114000000/http://www.br.terra.com/terramagazine/interna/0,,EI10781-OI4838527,00.html|archivedate=14 November 2012|deadurl=no|language=Spanish}}{{cite news|last=Ruiz|first=Gustavo|title=Mexican official: La Familia cartel chief is believed dead|url=http://www.salon.com/2010/12/10/lt_drug_war_mexico_12/|accessdate=15 November 2012|newspaper=[[Salon (website)|Salon]]|date=10 December 2010|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121114000000/http://www.salon.com/2010/12/10/lt_drug_war_mexico_12/|archivedate=14 November 2012|deadurl=no}} His second book, titled "They Call Me The Craziest One", is 13 chapters long and talks about his life, idealism, the origins of La Familia Michoacana, their battle against Los Zetas, and his rationale behind joining organized crime. The text reads like a diary and justifies his criminal activities under the rationale that just like others in Michoacán, the limited opportunities and his poor financial situation pushed him to get involved in the drug trade. In addition to that, Moreno González blamed the government for the existence of criminals.{{cite news|last=Medrano|first=Marcos|title=Capo plasmó idearios en dos libros para reclutar adeptos|url=http://www.redpolitica.mx/estados/capo-plasmo-idearios-en-dos-libros-para-reclutar-adeptos|accessdate=23 January 2014|newspaper=Red Política|date=20 January 2014|agency=[[El Universal (Mexico City)|El Universal]]|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6MqYqX18p?url=http://www.redpolitica.mx/estados/capo-plasmo-idearios-en-dos-libros-para-reclutar-adeptos|archivedate=23 January 2014|deadurl=no|language=Spanish}} As leader of La Familia Michoacana, Moreno González was in charge of forging alliances with other cartels. Reportedly, Moreno González met with several other high-ranking drug lords, including [[Fernando Sánchez Arellano]] of the [[Tijuana Cartel]]; [[Juan José Esparragoza Moreno]] of the [[Sinaloa Cartel]]; and [[Ezequiel Cárdenas Guillén]] of the [[Gulf Cartel]].{{cite news|last=Gómez|first=Francisco|title=El Chayo", clave en alianzas: expediente|url=http://www.eluniversal.com.mx/nacion/182602.html|accessdate=16 November 2012|newspaper=[[El Universal (Mexico City)|El Universal]]|date=17 December 2010|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6CD4yKzXZ?url=http://www.eluniversal.com.mx/nacion/182602.html|archivedate=16 November 2012|deadurl=no|language=Spanish}} In these agreements, the cartels allowed La Familia Michoacana to move drugs freely in their territories in exchange for their support in fighting off rival gangs like Los Zetas. In 2008, Moreno González agreed to send armed men to help [[Joaquín Guzmán Loera]] and [[Ismael Zambada García]] fight off rival cartels, a favor which granted him access to the drug corridors in Sinaloa and Sonora. In addition, his friendship with the Gulf Cartel leader [[Jorge Eduardo Costilla Sánchez]] allowed him access to the northeastern state of [[Tamaulipas]]. ===Philanthropy=== During his tenure as leader of La Familia Michoacana, Moreno González reportedly gave loans to farmers, funded schools and churches, financed drainage projects, and carried out several aid campaigns to help out the disadvantaged in the state of Michoacán. This, along with the manpower of the organization, allowed him get the support of several rural sectors in the state, where many served as informants and collaborators for the cartel.{{sfn|Levy|2011|p=132}} His wife was also known for organizing several self-help seminars in Apatzingán.{{cite news|title=Mexicans March in Support of 'Craziest' Drug Lord|url=http://www.foxnews.com/world/2010/12/12/mexicans-march-support-craziest-drug-lord/|accessdate=24 June 2013|newspaper=[[Fox News]]|date=12 December 2010|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101216063611/http://www.foxnews.com/world/2010/12/12/mexicans-march-support-craziest-drug-lord/|archivedate=16 December 2010 }} The support of La Familia Michoacana is rooted in family connections and local communities in Michoacán, and in the supposed exploitation of its citizens by the government.{{cite news|last=Weissenstein|first=Michael|title=At launching point of Mexico's drug war, quasi-religious cartel rules 6 years later|url=http://www.vancouversun.com/mobile/news/world-news/launching+point+Mexicos+drug+quasireligious+cartel+rules+years+later/7486157/story.html|accessdate=15 November 2012|newspaper=[[The Vancouver Sun]]|date=1 November 2011|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6CBXTfOnX?url=http://www.vancouversun.com/mobile/news/world-news/launching+point+Mexicos+drug+quasireligious+cartel+rules+years+later/7486157/story.html|archivedate=15 November 2012|deadurl=yes|df=dmy-all}} ==Alleged 2010 death== On 9 December 2010, the [[Federal Police (Mexico)|Mexican federal police]] surrounded the village of El Alcalde in [[Apatzingán]], [[Michoacán]] with more than 2,000 officers. Reportedly, Moreno González was at a local festival handing out Christmas presents to the villagers when he was tracked down by the authorities.{{cite news|last=Grillo|first=Ioan|title=Saint, knights and crystal meth; Mexico's bizarre cartel|url=http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/48232319/ns/world_news-americas/t/saint-knights-crystal-meth-mexicos-bizarre-cartel/#.UKRj8-Oe_DE|accessdate=15 November 2012|newspaper=[[MSNBC]]|date=18 June 2012|agency=[[Reuters]]|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6CBVyfksv?url=http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/48232319/ns/world_news-americas/t/saint-knights-crystal-meth-mexicos-bizarre-cartel/|archivedate=15 November 2012}}{{cite news|last=Tuckerman|first=Jo|title=Mexican drug cartel chief reported dead in gun skirmish|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2010/dec/10/mexico-la-familia-gang-leader|accessdate=22 June 2013|newspaper=[[The Guardian]]|date=10 December 2012|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101214053146/http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2010/dec/10/mexico-la-familia-gang-leader|archivedate=14 December 2010 |deadurl=no|location=Mexico City}} As the police troops drove into town, gunmen of La Familia Michoacana blocked the entrances with more than 40 burning trucks and cars. La Familia gunmen also surrounded the state capital of [[Morelia]] in an attempt to prevent the police from receiving reinforcements.{{cite news|title=Cops: Chief of La Familia Cartel, Nazario Moreno, Believed Dead After Mexican Shootout|url=http://www.cbsnews.com/8301-504083_162-20025353-504083.html|accessdate=14 November 2012|newspaper=[[CBS News]]|date=10 December 2010|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6CArAnvgP?url=http://www.cbsnews.com/8301-504083_162-20025353-504083.html|archivedate=14 November 2012|deadurl=no}} The shootout lasted about two days, and at least 11 deaths were confirmed.{{#tag:ref|Since the gunmen carried away the bodies of their partners during the firefight, it is impossible to know the exact number of people who were killed.{{cite news|last=Wilkinson|first=Tracy|title=La Familia cartel leader believed killed in Michoacan violence|url=http://articles.latimes.com/2010/dec/11/world/la-fg-mexico-drug-lord-20101211|accessdate=15 November 2012|newspaper=[[Los Angeles Times]]|date=11 December 2012|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6CBb4FHnX?url=http://articles.latimes.com/2010/dec/11/world/la-fg-mexico-drug-lord-20101211|archivedate=15 November 2012|deadurl=no}} The police commander, Elías Álvarez, who led the 2010 operation in Apatzingán, estimated that more than 50 people were killed.|group = A}} During the gun battle, the gunmen managed to carry out the bodies of their fallen comrades up the hills. The government reported at the time that Moreno González had been killed, but that the cartel took his body away.{{cite news|last=Lange|first=Jason|title=Mexican drug lord Moreno gunned down|url=http://uk.reuters.com/article/2010/12/10/uk-mexico-drugs-kingpin-idUKTRE6B957Q20101210|accessdate=14 November 2012|newspaper=[[Reuters]]|date=10 December 2010|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6CAqzi7Ro?url=http://uk.reuters.com/article/2010/12/10/uk-mexico-drugs-kingpin-idUKTRE6B957Q20101210|archivedate=14 November 2012|location=[[Mexico City]]}} This triggered rumors that he was alive and leading his cartel. However, the Mexican government denied such claims. Elías Álvarez, the commander of the 2010 police operation, said González's grave was in the mountains.{{cite news|last=Grillo|first=Ioan|title=Saint, knights and crystal meth; Mexico's bizarre cartel|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2012/07/18/oukwd-uk-mexico-drugs-knights-idAFBRE86H0WC20120718|accessdate=15 November 2012|newspaper=[[Reuters]]|date=18 July 2012|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6CBW3VXw5?url=http://www.reuters.com/article/2012/07/18/oukwd-uk-mexico-drugs-knights-idAFBRE86H0WC20120718|archivedate=15 November 2012}} 2014 reports from the Mexican government stated that Moreno González was possibly injured (but not killed) during the shootout.{{cite news|title=La Tuta y Kike Plancarte asumen el control de Los Templarios|url=http://www.proceso.com.mx/?p=366893|accessdate=11 March 2014|newspaper=[[Proceso (magazine)|Proceso]]|date=10 March 2014|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140311071449/http://www.proceso.com.mx/?p=366893|archivedate=11 March 2014|deadurl=no|language=Spanish}} For four years, the drug lord took advantage of the government's mistake to fall off the authorities's radar and continue to command the cartel behind the scenes.{{cite news|title=Era un secreto a voces que ‘El Chayo’ estaba vivo: Castillo|url=http://www.milenio.com/policia/muere_Nazario_Moreno-confirman_muerte_de_El_Chayo-templarios-Michoacan-Castillo_0_259774086.html|accessdate=11 March 2014|newspaper=[[Milenio]]|date=10 March 2014|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6O0G0Iq2n?url=http://www.milenio.com/policia/muere_Nazario_Moreno-confirman_muerte_de_El_Chayo-templarios-Michoacan-Castillo_0_259774086.html|archivedate=11 March 2014|deadurl=no|language=Spanish}} ===Background and aftermath=== The alleged death of Moreno González was considered one of the most significant government victories since the start of the drug war in 2006. [[La Familia Michoacana]] was the focus of the government because their stronghold, Michoacán state, is approximately four hours away from the country's capital, [[Mexico City]]. In addition, Michoacán is the homestate of former President [[Felipe Calderón]], who made it a top priority to pacify it.{{cite news|last=Cave|first=Damian|title=Mexicans Suggest That They Killed a Drug Leader|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2010/12/11/world/americas/11mexico.html|accessdate=15 November 2012|newspaper=[[The New York Times]]|date=10 December 2010|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6CBZN0KZT?url=http://www.nytimes.com/2010/12/11/world/americas/11mexico.html?_r=0|archivedate=15 November 2012|deadurl=no|df=dmy-all}} A few days after the shootout, several people carried out a peace march in Apatzingán expressing their support for the cartel with banners that read "Nazario will always live in our hearts," among others.{{cite news|last=Hernandez|first=Daniel|title=Michoacan peace march turns into rally for La Familia drug lord|url=http://latimesblogs.latimes.com/laplaza/2010/12/peace-march-rally-drug-lord-michoacan-familia-mexico.html|accessdate=15 November 2012|newspaper=[[Los Angeles Times]]|date=13 December 2010|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6CBilBfCf?url=http://latimesblogs.latimes.com/laplaza/2010/12/peace-march-rally-drug-lord-michoacan-familia-mexico.html|archivedate=15 November 2012|deadurl=no}} Others protested against the presence of the federal forces in the state, and argued that the federal government—not the cartels—were responsible for increasing the [[Mexican Drug War|violence in the country]]. Through several banners hung on bridges throughout the state of Michoacán, La Familia Michoacana publicly announced that they were open to the possibility of creating a "truce" (ceasefire) with the Mexican government throughout December 2010 and January 2011 to prove that they were not the source of the violence. The Mexican authorities "summarily rejected" the agreement.{{cite news|last=Hernandez|first=Daniel|title=Mexico: La Familia offers to cease January 'activities' in public letter|url=http://latimesblogs.latimes.com/laplaza/2011/01/la-familia-michoacan-letter-truce.html|accessdate=15 November 2012|newspaper=[[Los Angeles Times]]|date=4 January 2011|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6CBjTTpY2?url=http://latimesblogs.latimes.com/laplaza/2011/01/la-familia-michoacan-letter-truce.html|archivedate=15 November 2012|deadurl=no}} After Moreno Gonzalez was reported dead, [[José de Jesús Méndez Vargas]] took the lead of La Familia Michoacana. The other cartel leader, Servando Gómez Martínez (alias "La Tuta"), fought Méndez Vargas for control of the group and eventually formed the [[Knights Templar Cartel]], a drug cartel and pseudo-religious splinter group.{{cite news|last=Wilkinson|first=Tracy|title=Mexico arrest may do little to change the drug cartel equation|url=http://articles.latimes.com/2011/jun/23/world/la-fg-mexico-drugwar-20110623|accessdate=15 November 2012|newspaper=[[Los Angeles Times]]|date=23 June 2011|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6CBg24ZlQ?url=http://articles.latimes.com/2011/jun/23/world/la-fg-mexico-drugwar-20110623|archivedate=15 November 2012|deadurl=no}} The cartel was headed by Moreno González, followed by Gómez Martínez, [[Dionisio Loya Plancarte]] (alias "El Tío"), and [[Enrique Plancarte Solís]] (alias "Kike Plancarte"), in that order. However, given that the Mexican government believed that Moreno González had been killed in 2010, Gómez Martínez was regarded as the first-in-command.{{cite news|title=La Empresa que originó a Los Templarios|url=http://www.milenio.com/policia/nacimiento-templarios-familia-michoacana-michoacan_0_259774453.html|accessdate=11 March 2014|newspaper=[[Milenio]]|date=10 March 2014|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6O0G673WT?url=http://www.milenio.com/policia/nacimiento-templarios-familia-michoacana-michoacan_0_259774453.html|archivedate=11 March 2014|deadurl=no|language=Spanish}} Since its creation, the Knights Templar Cartel became a greater security concern for the Mexican government; it began to extort lime farmers, cutters, and packers, as well as people who worked in the avocado business in Michoacán.{{cite news|last=Stevenson|first=Mark|title=Knights Templar Drug Cartel Burns Michoacan, Western State In Mexico|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2013/05/22/knights-templar-drug-cartel-michoacan-mexico_n_3322373.html|accessdate=10 March 2014|newspaper=[[The Huffington Post]]|date=22 May 2013|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130613185116/http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2013/05/22/knights-templar-drug-cartel-michoacan-mexico_n_3322373.html|archivedate=13 June 2013 |deadurl=no}} The cartel also stole minerals from the state's reserves to later ship to China for sale on the black market.{{cite news|title=Controlan Caballeros templarios exportación de mineral de hierro|url=http://www.jornada.unam.mx/2014/01/03/politica/005n1pol|accessdate=10 March 2014|newspaper=[[La Jornada]]|date=2 January 2014|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140310102403/http://www.jornada.unam.mx/2014/01/03/politica/005n1pol|archivedate=10 March 2014 |deadurl=no|language=Spanish}} Killings, extortions, kidnappings, and arson attacks against Michoacán residents and local businesses increased.{{cite news|last=Althaus|first=Dudley|title=Who are Mexico's Knights Templar?|url=http://www.globalpost.com/dispatch/news/regions/americas/mexico/130602/explainer-who-are-mexicos-knights-templar|accessdate=11 March 2014|newspaper=[[GlobalPost]]|date=4 June 2014|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140212022608/http://www.globalpost.com/dispatch/news/regions/americas/mexico/130602/explainer-who-are-mexicos-knights-templar|archivedate=12 February 2014 |deadurl=no}} In response to the cartel's activities, ''autodefensa'' (vigilante/self-defense) groups began to emerge in Michoacán in 2011,{{cite news|last=Grillo|first=Ioan|title=Mexican Vigilantes Beat Back Ruthless Knights Templar Cartel|url=http://time.com/5755/mexico-vigilantes-knights-templar-cartel-michoacan/|accessdate=10 March 2014|newspaper=[[TIME (magazine)|TIME]]|date=19 January 2014|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140309032357/http://time.com/5755/mexico-vigilantes-knights-templar-cartel-michoacan/|archivedate=9 March 2014 |deadurl=no}} and gained significant momentum in February 2013 when they began to push the cartel outside of the [[Tierra Caliente (Mexico)|Tierra Caliente]] region.{{cite news|title='Slain' Mexico cartel leader dies a second time|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/the_americas/mexico-government-is-100-pct-that-drug-capo-killed/2014/03/09/fc63e8b4-a7f2-11e3-8a7b-c1c684e2671f_story.html|accessdate=10 March 2014|newspaper=[[The Washington Post]]|date=9 March 2014|agency=[[The Associated Press]]|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6O0GAUT60?url=http://www.washingtonpost.com/world/the_americas/mexico-government-is-100-pct-that-drug-capo-killed/2014/03/09/fc63e8b4-a7f2-11e3-8a7b-c1c684e2671f_story.html|archivedate=11 March 2014|deadurl=no}} President [[Enrique Peña Nieto]] sent in more federal troops to Michoacán on January 2014 initially with the intent to disarm the informal groups. However, that plan was quickly abandoned following some resistance, and the government decided to sign an agreement that month with the ''autodefensas'' to combat insecurity together.{{cite news|last=LaFranchi|first=Howard|title=Mexico's vigilantes: the aftershocks of ousting a cartel (+video)|url=http://www.csmonitor.com/World/Americas/2014/0309/Mexico-s-vigilantes-the-aftershocks-of-ousting-a-cartel-video|accessdate=10 March 2014|newspaper=[[The Christian Science Monitor]]|date=9 March 2014|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140310023439/http://www.csmonitor.com/World/Americas/2014/0309/Mexico-s-vigilantes-the-aftershocks-of-ousting-a-cartel-video|archivedate=10 March 2014 |deadurl=no}}{{cite news|last=McDermott|first=Jeremy|title=Breaking News: Mythical Leader of Mexico Cartel Dead - For Sure This Time|url=http://www.insightcrime.org/news-analysis/mythical-leader-of-mexico-drug-cartel-dead-for-sure-this-time|accessdate=10 March 2014|newspaper=[[InSight Crime]]|date=9 March 2014|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6O0GZBjxJ?url=http://www.insightcrime.org/news-analysis/mythical-leader-of-mexico-drug-cartel-dead-for-sure-this-time|archivedate=11 March 2014|deadurl=no}} ===Allegations of having survived the attempted police capture=== Given that Moreno González's body was never recovered from the December 2010 shootout where officials said he was killed, there were rumors that he was alive and secretly leading the [[Knights Templar Cartel]], the split-off group of La Familia Michoacana. On June 2011, members of La Familia Michoacana set up several public banners throughout the state of [[Guerrero]] with written messages directed to the former President Calderón and his security spokesman [[Alejandro Poiré]]. The banners proclaimed that Moreno González was in fact alive and leading the Knights Templar Cartel, and that the government was allegedly covering him up. The rumors were immediately denied by the Mexican government, which stood firm that the drug lord was killed by federal forces on December 9, 2010.{{cite news|title=La Familia Michoacana deja mensaje para Calderón y Poiré|url=http://www.blogdelnarco.com/2011/06/la-familia-michoacana-deja-mensaje-para.html|accessdate=24 June 2013|newspaper=[[Blog del Narco]]|date=June 2011|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6HbXemPl9?url=http://www.blogdelnarco.com/2011/06/la-familia-michoacana-deja-mensaje-para.html|archivedate=24 June 2013|language=Spanish}}{{cite news|last=Ramsey|first=Geoffrey|title=Is Slain Drug Boss 'El Chayo' Still Alive?|url=http://www.insightcrime.org/news-briefs/is-slain-drug-boss-el-chayo-still-alive|accessdate=24 June 2013|newspaper=[[InSight Crime]]|date=12 October 2011|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6HbXk7ual?url=http://www.insightcrime.org/news-briefs/is-slain-drug-boss-el-chayo-still-alive|archivedate=24 June 2013}} Rumors sparked again in October 2011 following the arrest of Mario Buenrostro Quiroz, a drug trafficker who headed a [[Mexico City]]-based gang known as Los Aboytes. In a videotaped police confession, he told authorities that Moreno González was still alive and heading the cartel. Intelligence agency [[InSight Crime]] said the rumors were probably part of a campaign of the Knights Templar Cartel to win prestige from La Familia Michoacana by saying that their leader is in fact alive and still supporting the group. On 27 October 2012, the [[Mexican Army]] raided a safe house in Apatzingán where they believed the drug lord [[Enrique Plancarte Solís]] was hiding. Though the raid was ultimately unsuccessful because Plancarte Solís managed to avoid capture by sending several gunmen from his inner circle to battle off the soldiers, the authorities discovered several documents written for Moreno González. The Army gave the documents to the intelligence agency [[SIEDO]] for further investigation.{{cite news |title=Hallan indicios de vida de narco mexicano Nazario Moreno |url=http://m.noticias.univision.com/narcotrafico/noticias/article/2012-11-27/nazario-moreno-chayo-chango-vivo-la-familia-michoacana-indicios?id=1358829 |accessdate=26 January 2017 |newspaper=[[Univision]] |date=27 October 2012 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130624020609/http://m.noticias.univision.com/narcotrafico/noticias/article/2012-11-27/nazario-moreno-chayo-chango-vivo-la-familia-michoacana-indicios?id=1358829 |archivedate=24 June 2013 |language=Spanish}}{{cite news|last=Vega|first=Aurora|title=Hallan indicios de vida de El Chayo ex líder de La Familia Michoacana|url=http://www.excelsior.com.mx/node/871847|accessdate=24 June 2013|newspaper=[[Excélsior]]|date=27 October 2012|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6HbWhzDtG?url=http://www.excelsior.com.mx/node/871847|archivedate=24 June 2013|language=Spanish}} Many Michoacán natives believed that Moreno González was alive; he was widely believed to have made a public appearance in Morelia in 2012 after his son was killed in a motorcycle accident. According to an unnamed official, his sister went to the morgue to reclaim the body of his son before the autopsy. When the coroner refused to give her the body, Moreno González paid him a visit and convinced him to give up the body. In fears of reprisals, local media outlets self-censored and did not report on the death of his son. Those who wrecked his son were reportedly kidnapped by Moreno González men and killed. In addition, one militia leader from the town of [[Coalcomán de Vázquez Pallares|Coalcomán]] reported seeing him dressed as [[Saint Francis of Assisi]], baptizing people, and leading his henchmen. There was no concrete evidence of Moreno González being alive. However, since no autopsy was performed, there was no evidence of him being dead either.{{cite news|last=Althaus|first=Dudley|title=Ghost of 'The Craziest One' is Alive in Mexico|url=http://www.insightcrime.org/news-analysis/ghost-of-the-craziest-one-is-alive-in-mexico|accessdate=24 June 2013|newspaper=[[InSight Crime]]|date=11 June 2012|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6HbX00xy8?url=http://www.insightcrime.org/news-analysis/ghost-of-the-craziest-one-is-alive-in-mexico|archivedate=24 June 2013}} In January 2014, Gregorio López, a priest of Apatzingán, reported that Moreno González ordered a self-imposed curfew in the city and threatened to burn down businesses that did not comply with the order. That week Michoacán had a series of violent episodes after the state's ''autodefensa'' (vigilante) groups—which emerged in February 2013 to fight the Knights Templar Cartel—attempted to move into several municipalities to fight the cartel. The priest said in an interview that there were rumors that the drug lord met with "La Tuta" for lunch in La Cucha, a ranch outside of Apatzingán.{{cite news|title=La Tuta y Nazario comieron juntos justo cuando llegaron los federales a Michoacán: surrounding these allegations were around since Moreno González was declared dead by the Mexican government in 2010. The mysticism and spiritual teachings of the drug lord have played an important role in the Knights Templar Cartel's propaganda and recruitment in Michoacán. By spreading such rumors, the cartel hoped to gain a level of consensus from the public in their fight against the self-defense militias and state forces in the state.{{cite news|last=Lohmuller|first=Michael|title=Rumors Fuel The Legend of the "Narco-Saint|url=http://www.insightcrime.org/news-briefs/mexicos-narco-saint-stokes-passions-in-embattled-territory|accessdate=7 February 2014|newspaper=[[InSight Crime]]|date=6 February 2014|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6NCebdHjA?url=http://www.insightcrime.org/news-briefs/mexicos-narco-saint-stokes-passions-in-embattled-territory|archivedate=7 February 2014}}{{cite news|title=Nazario Moreno: la leyenda de la resurrección del "primer santo narco|url=http://noticias.terra.com/america-latina/nazario-moreno-la-leyenda-de-la-resurreccion-del-primer-santo-narco,513ae92bcbdf3410VgnCLD2000000dc6eb0aRCRD.html|accessdate=7 February 2014|newspaper=[[Terra Networks]]|date=4 February 2014|agency=[[BBC Mundo]]|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6NCeiqCGr?url=http://noticias.terra.com/america-latina/nazario-moreno-la-leyenda-de-la-resurreccion-del-primer-santo-narco,513ae92bcbdf3410VgnCLD2000000dc6eb0aRCRD.html|archivedate=7 February 2014|language=Spanish|deadurl=yes|df=dmy-all}} ==Veneration== {{Infobox saint | name = Nazario Moreno González | image = | imagesize = | alt = | caption = | titles = Saint Nazario, Representative of God, Knight of the Town, Protector of the Poorest | birth_date = 8 March 1970 | birth_place = Apatzingán, Mexico | home_town = | residence = | death_date = 9 March 2014 (aged 44) | death_place = Tumbiscatío, Mexico | venerated_in = [[La Familia Michoacana]]
[[Knights Templar Cartel]]
[[Mexico]]
[[Folk Catholicism]] | beatified_date = | beatified_place = | beatified_by = | canonized_date = | canonized_place = | canonized_by = | major_shrine = Holanda and Apatzingán, Mexico | feast_day = | attributes = | patronage = People of [[Michoacán]], protection from harm, protection from [[Los Zetas]] | issues = | suppressed_date = | suppressed_by = | influences = | influenced = | tradition = | major_works = }} After Moreno González's reported death in 2010, Michoacán natives reportedly began to worship him as a saint, "drawing attention to the links between narco-culture and religion."{{cite news|last=Knott|first=Tracy|title=Dead Drug Boss 'Sainted' in Mexico|url=http://www.insightcrime.org/news-briefs/dead-drug-boss-sainted-in-mexico|accessdate=14 November 2012|newspaper=[[InSight Crime]]|date=12 July 2012|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6CArQiDKm?url=http://www.insightcrime.org/news-briefs/dead-drug-boss-sainted-in-mexico|archivedate=14 November 2012|deadurl=no}} In the region of [[Apatzingán]], people created altars with statues and photos in honor of him. The figurines are often dressed in tunics similar to the [[Knights Templar]], and had prayers calling him Saint Nazario. ''[[Reforma]]'' newspaper reported that Moreno González had his own prayer: "Oh Lord Almighty, free me from all sins, give me protection through Saint Nazario."{{cite news|title=En Michoacán veneran al capo Nazario Moreno|url=http://www.proceso.com.mx/?p=313729|accessdate=12 July 2012|newspaper=[[Proceso (magazine)|Proceso]]|date=10 July 2012|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6CArHtGrn?url=http://www.proceso.com.mx/?p=313729|archivedate=14 November 2012|deadurl=no|language=Spanish|df=dmy-all}} These altars are found in the village of Holanda, on the hill of El Cerrito de la Cruz, and in Apatzingán. Villagers have noted that they had been forced to venerate the criminal under threat of armed force by the gang members.{{cite news|last=Archibold|first=Randal|title=A Quandary for Mexico as Vigilantes Rise|url=http://mobile.nytimes.com/2014/01/16/world/americas/a-quandary-for-mexico-as-vigilantes-rise.html|accessdate=16 January 2014|newspaper=[[The New York Times]]|date=14 January 2014|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6MfoxXNAK?url=http://mobile.nytimes.com/2014/01/16/world/americas/a-quandary-for-mexico-as-vigilantes-rise.html|archivedate=16 January 2014|language=Spanish}} Throughout his criminal career, Moreno González promoted La Familia Michoacana as an organization that existed to protect the people in Michoacán, where he carried out several campaigns that implemented curfews, punished drinkers, and attacked [[Los Zetas]], whom he claimed had corroded the morality of the state and community. The prayers that are now dedicated to Moreno González now refer to him as the "Representative of God," the "Protector of the poorest," and as the "Knight of the towns." Such behavior proves that [[La Familia Michoacana]]'s religious campaign influenced the local area. The area where the altars are located is reportedly patrolled by ''Los 12 apóstoles'' ('12 apostles'), the security body that allegedly protected Moreno González. ==Death== At around 7:00 a.m. on 9 March 2014, the Mexican Army and Navy pinpointed Moreno González's whereabouts in [[Tumbiscatío|Tumbiscatío, Michoacán]].{{cite news|last=Mosso|first=Rubén|title=Confirman muerte de 'El Chayo'|url=http://www.milenio.com/policia/Confirman-muerte-Chayo_0_259174388.html|accessdate=10 March 2014|newspaper=[[Milenio]]|date=10 March 2014|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6O0Gdjf45?url=http://www.milenio.com/policia/Confirman-muerte-Chayo_0_259174388.html|archivedate=11 March 2014|deadurl=no|language=Spanish}} When they tried to apprehend him, the drug lord opened fire at the security forces before being killed in the fire exchange.{{cite news|last=Shoichet|first=Catherine E.|title=Notorious Mexican cartel leader Nazario Moreno dead — again|url=http://www.cnn.com/2014/03/09/world/americas/mexico-drug-lord-nazario-moreno-killed/|accessdate=10 March 2014|newspaper=[[CNN]]|date=9 March 2014|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140310084047/http://www.cnn.com/2014/03/09/world/americas/mexico-drug-lord-nazario-moreno-killed/|archivedate=10 March 2014 |deadurl=no}} Mexico's [[Procuraduría General de la República]] (PGR) officially confirmed his identity through DNA examinations and fingerprint identification. '''Philander Stephens''' (1788 – July 8, 1842) was a [[Jacksonian Democrats|Jacksonian]] member of the [[U.S. House of Representatives]] from [[Pennsylvania]]. Philander Stephens was born near [[Montrose, Pennsylvania]]. He served as coroner in 1815, county commissioner in 1818 and [[sheriff]] in 1821. He was a member of the [[Pennsylvania House of Representatives]] in 1824 and 1825. Stephens was elected as a Jacksonian to the [[21st United States Congress|Twenty-first]] and [[22nd United States Congress|Twenty-second]] Congresses. He served as chairman of the [[United States House Committee on Expenditures in the Department of the Treasury]] during the Twenty-second Congress. He was not a candidate for renomination in [[United States House election, 1832|1832]]. He resumed agricultural and mercantile pursuits and died probably in [[Springville Township, Pennsylvania]]. Interment in Stephens Burying Ground in [[Dimock Township, Pennsylvania]]. ==Sources== {{CongBio|S000859}} *[http://politicalgraveyard.com/bio/stephens.html The Political Graveyard] {{s-start}} {{s-par|us-hs}} {{USRepSuccessionBox | state=Pennsylvania | district=9 | before=[[Samuel McKean]]
